sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: In a basketball game, a player has a 70% chance of making a free throw. If the player takes 10 free throws, what is the probability that they will make exactly 7 of them?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(x) = C(n, x) * p^x * (1-p)^(n-x)

where P(x) is the probability of making exactly x free throws, C(n, x) is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time (also written as nCx), p is the probability of making a free throw (0.7 in this case), and n is the total number of free throws taken (10 in this case).

We want to find the probability of making exactly 7 free throws, so we'll plug in x = 7:

P(7) = C(10, 7) * 0.7^7 * (1-0.7)^(10-7)

First, let's calculate C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 free throws from 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / (5040 * 6)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / 30240
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, let's plug this back into the formula:

P(7) = 120 * 0.7^7 * 0.3^3

Calculate the powers:

P(7) = 120 * 0.0823543 * 0.027

Finally, multiply everything together:

P(7) ≈ 120 * 0.0823543 * 0.027 ≈ 0.2668

So, the probability of the player making exactly 7 free throws out of 10 is approximately 26.68%.
